column8: Misty Mornings, Stunning Views  A Peaceful Escape into Sri Lanka‚Äôs Highlands
column11: Horton Plains National Park is unlike anywhere else I visited in Sri Lanka ‚Äî high-altitude grasslands, cloud forests, waterfalls, and epic cliffside views all wrapped into one peaceful hike. If you're looking for a break from the heat and beaches, this is a fantastic escape into cool, fresh mountain air. We started the 9.5 km loop trail just after sunrise. The park opens at 6:00 AM, and I highly recommend getting there early. Not only do you beat the crowds, but you also have a better chance of catching clear skies before the mist rolls in over World‚Äôs End  the highlight of the hike. The trail is mostly flat with a few rocky or muddy sections. It takes about 2.5 to 3 hours depending on your pace and how often you stop to admire the scenery. Along the way, you‚Äôll pass through rolling plains, dense forest, and misty stretches that feel almost otherworldly. Wildlife is shy but present we saw sambars (large deer), plenty of birds, and lots of interesting plants. When you reach World‚Äôs End, the view is jaw-dropping  a sheer cliff dropping almost 800 meters, with tea estates and distant hills stretching into the horizon. Mini World‚Äôs End comes a bit earlier on the trail and offers a similar, though less dramatic, viewpoint. After that, Baker‚Äôs Falls is a lovely place to stop, rest, and enjoy the sound of rushing water. Horton Plains isn‚Äôt about adrenaline  it‚Äôs about quiet, natural beauty. It‚Äôs not crowded (especially early), and the air is cool and refreshing. You feel totally immersed in nature.

column8: Horton Plains ‚Äì A Serene Highland Escape
column11: Horton Plains is a breathtaking gem in Sri Lanka, offering misty landscapes, rolling grasslands, and rich biodiversity. The highlight is World‚Äôs End, a dramatic cliff with stunning views, especially at sunrise. The trek is moderate, surrounded by cloud forests, wildflowers, and occasional sambar deer. Baker‚Äôs Falls adds to the charm with its refreshing beauty. The cool climate makes it ideal for hiking, but mornings are best before the mist sets in. A must-visit for nature lovers, hikers, and photographers seeking serene beauty. Horton Plains truly captures the untouched essence of Sri Lanka‚Äôs highlands.

We visited Horton Plains, and it was truly one of the highlights of my trip to Sri Lanka. The trail is well-marked and not too difficult, perfect for moderate-level hikers. The views from World‚Äôs End and Mini World‚Äôs End were absolutely stunning, especially before the clouds rolled in. Bakers Falls was also beautiful and worth the small detour. We spotted some sambar deer along the way, and the landscape is incredibly unique, a mix of grassland and cloud forest that you don‚Äôt see often. The weather was cool and refreshing, which made the walk even more enjoyable. Do bring water, a light jacket, and good walking shoes. Also, no plastic bags are allowed inside the park, which is great for conservation. Highly recommended for nature lovers, photographers, and anyone looking to escape into peaceful surroundings.

Beautiful nature greenery!  Weather was amazing in April when I visited. Had a tour guide for my walk there. Started to walk at 7.30am.  Mist and cool weather helped to keep me energised. We had a very early start in a tuk tuk from Nuwara Eliya at  5am!  Our driver was amazing and put the sides down as it was really cold.  We stopped to watch the sunrise which was lovely and continued to the park.  He has seen leopards here but not on the paths to worlds end.  There is a toilet opposite the ticket counter, then you walk a bit to the museum and the entry just after that where they check for plastic.  They will remove stickers or labels off bottles.  We were fine and did the walk  clockwise, it was nice and relatively easy.  Wear good walking shoes and our accommodation had supplied us a packed breakfast which was really nice of them.  We sat and ate that at worlds end and got a lovely view.  It seemed a popular spot to sit and have breakfast.  There was only 6 people there (3 of us) which was really peaceful. The clouds come in pretty quick.  We enjoyed bakers falls and walked back.  You strip off your layers as you go along as it does get quite warm fast. As we were leaving a lot of people were arriving, the view was long gone but it is still a nice walk.  The alpine grasses remind me of New Zealand. It is expensive to enter, I enjoyed it but wouldn't do it again, would rather do another trek with a guide here.

Each step revealed a new wonder, from colorful bird species flitting through the trees to vibrant wildflowers blooming along the path. The sense of tranquility and serenity that permeated Norton Plain was truly remarkable. We found ourselves immersed in a peaceful oasis where time seemed to stand still, allowing us to appreciate the simple joys of nature and savor the present moment. Whether we were watching the sunset over the hills or stargazing under the clear night sky, each experience at Norton Plain was imbued with a sense of wonder and awe. In conclusion, our time at Norton Plain was a true escape into paradise, where the beauty of nature and the warmth of the local community combined to create an unforgettable experience. This hidden gem in the hill country of Sri Lanka has left a lasting impression on us, and we cannot wait to return to its peaceful embrace once again. If you are seeking a place of natural beauty, tranquility, and cultural richness, look no further than Norton Plain ‚Äì a destination that will capture your heart and soothe your soul.

It is a nice location, with good views. However, tourists should not waste your money here, as you will pay 150 times the local price. Took about 4hrs for a 9.5km trail. Please note that this is not a trail for casual walkers, or the young or elderly. There is no such warning or information about the conditions of the trail when you are buying the entry tickets. Visiting Horton Plains in Sri Lanka offers a unique experience where the lush greenery and serene landscapes remind one of the Scottish Highlands or the Irish countryside. The highlight of the area is the 'World's End' - a spectacular viewpoint with breathtaking vistas. However, travelers should note that reaching this spot is quite a challenge. The path to World's End is not just a leisurely stroll; it involves navigating steep, uneven terrain with multiple climbs. It's essential to wear comfortable, sturdy shoes to tackle these paths. This trek might not be suitable for those with physical limitations, knee injuries, or families traveling with small children due to its demanding nature. Moreover, it's crucial to consider the weather before planning your visit. The rainy season can be particularly hazardous in this region, with risks of sudden floods. Therefore, it‚Äôs best to avoid monsoon periods for a safer and more enjoyable experience. In summary, Horton Plains offers a stunning natural escape for the active and adventurous traveler, but it requires good preparation and a consideration of physical abilities. It's a place that leaves you in awe of nature's beauty, but also reminds you of its demands

Went to Horton place this morning. At 5 o'clock in the tuk tuk to drive an hour from Nuwara Eliya. We got there at 6am. There was already quite a line of drivers in front of the cash register, which opens at 6 am. The entrance fee was even more expensive than the $25. No further animals were seen in the area. I thought it was an exciting idea that the leopard is also walking around there. Apparently it doesn't attack humans ;-) At the starting point your bag will be opened and you will have to take out everything that is in the plastic. They offer paper bags. They take the labels off your water bottles. They were allowed inside. You can walk left and right. We went left and walked the more difficult route when you could choose. We didn't realize that at first and we wondered how all the 'oldies' were going to do this. You walk through very narrow, densely overgrown paths with an abyss next to you. Encountered 2 x toilets. Everything looks neat. It is quite a tough walk (9 km) with climbing and descending. Our legs were quite sore (also because we had only slept a few hours). It took us 3 hours. It is a completely different landscape than what you see elsewhere in the area.

We started our hike through Horton Plains early in the morning to catch a sunrise over the misty hills and terrains. What can I say, it was definitely worth waking up so early. We saw plenty of deers eating fresh grass even before we entered the main gate of the park, and then had an enjoyable walk along the route towards Baker's Falls. There are two options: you can start with the Falls and finish by the Little World's End or vice versa. We chose the first option and did not regret it. After we saw the sunrise, the sun quickly disappeared behind the clouds and we did not see it much until we reached the falls and the skies became blue. We took wonderful photos and had our packed breakfast right there on a bench, which was so romantic and enjoyable. When we continued our route towards the World's End, we realized how right we were in taking that path - we almost always hiked down rather than climbing up and it made our trekking way more comfortable and less tiring. The day before we hiked the Adam's Peak, so we could not feel our legs and feet after that and this path we chose turned out to be helpful :) Unfortunately, when we reached the World's End, a big cloud hung on top and covered all the view. We waited for 30 minutes and the situation remained the same. We still were pleased with the hike and the World's End because there was a certain mystery in this endless mist over the edge. You can literally feel you are on the edge of nowhere. P.S. In my opinion, you won't need a guide to hike Horton Plains. It is super easy and it is impossible to get lost on the way. There is literally only one path and it is a round journey, so whatever way you choose - you will end up in the same place. Only if a lady is solo and scared of being attacked or something??? But generally, for me it seemed peaceful and safe. And if a leopard comes out from a bush, I don't think that having a guide will be helpful right??))) Also the time you will spend there will be at least 4-5 hrs if you do not want to run along the whole route and wish to take nice pictures and just enjoy the nature around you. So don't listen to people who tell it is like a 3-hour hike. Maybe, if you don't complete the whole circle..)

This is not a tough trip at all. Easy terrain wich results in amazing view. We started the trip at 06:00 am Where there were frost all over the Plains. The trip is around 8-9km alltogether. You can also see some wild animals there as well.

Very disappointed in this. Billed as a 'soft hike' but no way! One needed proper walking shoes and at times we were scrambling down a cliff (almost) and then walking up a river bed and this was meant to be the so-called 'easy' way. I don't see how visitors with young children could do this walk nor elderly. Only saw two birds and a 'stuffed' deer at the entrance to the park. Nature attraction - huh! We thought it was quite ordinary and for some of it like moorland in the UK. It took 3 1/2 hours solid walking to do 11.1 km.

I travel a fair bit.  I'm used to long treks.  I don't mind a tough walk.  But... THIS WAS UNREAL!!! Once past the first, flat half mile or so you encounter much more difficult "paths".  You literally have to haul yourself over boulder strewn pathways, watch for tree roots to trip over (I did fall), scramble down steep, smooth ravines with no foot holds, and do this for about 9km.  To top it all someone up ahead of us upset a bees nest and we had to flee for safety.  Unfortunately, 3 of our group got hospitalized with stings.  The really disappointing thing is that the trek wasn't worth the effort.  Other than the bees and a couple of deer at the starter hut we saw no wildlife at all.  It was also misty so no view at World's End.  With it having rained in the morning the stones were also very slippery.  Other than seeing the waterfall it was a miserable time for me.  Check the pictures for the sort of terrain you'll be covering.  Unbelievable.
The go to place for me in Sri Lanka. Love the clean and cold air. The most peaceful place on earth so far for me.

Very beautiful place and view. Best nature attraction place. You can see mini worlds end and great worlds end also beautiful water fall there. You can see some sumber deers,monkeys and birds. Lizard and many more creatures. You can join with me to visit horton plains by dialing 0777 829339.

Read so much about World End at Horton Plain. We like to visit. I am also expecting the long walk, but never did I realise that the 9.5km walk is really not simple, at least for me. The path initially was easy, as it is flat, but once entered the grassland, the path was rough with obstacles along the way. Ups & downs, under shade of the trees. Open space grassland path is easier to walk but under hot sun. We did not see any animals at all. However when reaching the mini world and hike another 1 km to the World End and further 2km Baker's Fall is really a reward. Another few km to the exit, for unfit people like me must reconsider. The path is a loop. I would say it is good for those who like hiking. Entrance fee is not cheap too. LKR7, 670 for 2 foreigners, 1 local, parking, tax.

A wonderful walk with beautiful views over the hills and lake. Deer walked down the slopes, the colors of the landscape and the nice waterfall...we enjoyed it very much. Advise: because of some rocky parts you need proper shoes.

Beautiful National Park but go early in the morning. It gets hot in the day. It is not crowded but we had a hard time at one lookout trying to take photos of the view without a lot of 'selfie taking' tourists in the way. I think the earlier you go the better. Leave your plastic at home as they do not allow anything in. For example they cut the plastic labels off water bottles which is a great initiative. I wish all countries were this considerate of their national parks.

After leaving my hotel at 5am and then walking for 9.5km over uneven ground I thought the Views at Bakers falls and Worlds end were ok , but nothing special .You need to get there early to avoid the heat , but wear layers as it's cold in the morning .Wear good walking shoes

This park is located covering the top of the mountain range in the area. The most popular hike leaves the ranger area complex and heads off along a very poorly maintained and rugged track to Worlds End. Here the risks are of being blown over the 900 metre fall protected by only razor wire. The views however are worth the risk. Once there the path? continues on to baxter falls. The scenery is great and the falls are worth a visit, continue on from the falls to do a loop and return the rangers area/car park.

Superb and Demanding trek.  Lots of climbing up and down, so not for the weak-kneed.  Terrific terrain with parts similar to Scottish country-side in summer.  Good environmental consciousness.  Unspoilt and prestine beauty.  Could have better facilities for refreshments and toilet before you enter main trekking circuit of 9.5 kilometers.

Nice yet challenging trek, very refreshing and easy on the mind and soul Very clean breaths of air and surreal visual experience Leave your electronics behind if you are planning on going here Would definitely recommend if you need a getaway This defined the mesmerising beauty that is Sri lanka

We had a lovely walk around the park and saw the main sights plus lots of bird life.  There were quite a lot of people also walking. The attendants were very strict about controlling litter and stopping people dropping plastic bottles, which was good. The visitors centre needs updating; it seemed very tired. The cafe was appalling; the people running in had no interest in looking after customers, the coffee was disgusting and they tried to rip us off by charging more than 10 x the price.  We think the park should upgrade the cafe and find staff able to provide much better service and products for the many visitors. It was unacceptable. The toilets next to the cafe were dirty and poor. The ones next to the visitor centre were much better. If you charge people a high fee to enter the park it is reasonable for them to expect decent facilities.

Since it is really difficult to find anything concerning the exact cost of horton plains, I took a picture of our ticket. As you can see, we (2 foreigners, our driver & a tuktuk) paid 7534.08 LKR. Prices vary according to vehicle, from what I could tell. We also paid the tuktuk driver 3500 LKR to pick us up in Nuwara Eliya at 5am and return around noon. All in all, it's a very nice park with beautiful viewpoints and nice waterfalls - but it's also expensive (compared to sri lankan standards) and they should really add more ticket counters. We had to wait for half an hour in the freezing cold because many people wanted to get in early in the morning & there was only one counter! It's worth it to go early though, seeing the sunrise from horton plains was amazing.
This really isnt worth the money. ¬£34 for a couple to walk along a path and see 2 viewpoints and a waterfall. We thought the drive up to the park was more impressive. ..................

We were very lucky to have a totally clear day so could fully appreciate the magnificence of this place. The tracks are tricky in places so you need walking sandals or boots. We passed people in flip flops which is bonkers. Go early as the clouds build up and you would loose the spectacular views from Worlds End.
Must visit place .if it's not rain it's worth to visit . And 5 to 5 30 am start from nuware liay . One hour drive from nuware liay to Horton plains . The hiking will around 3 hrs . Worth
Nice environment . Neat place . Beautiful  nature . You can walk to the worlds end. Plz save the place

This was a lovely National Park which is best seen in the early morning. We were greeted by some samba deer and wild boar. There is a 3 hour, 9 km walk. The path is up and down, rocks and steps which most ages can conquer. (I did!) The toilet facilities leave a lot to be desired however. There is a fee to enter the park and it would be beneficial if the fees paid could go to the upgrade of these toilets. Other than that set back it was a lovely place to go.

Interesting part of the tour of our trip.  We were advised to go very early having left our hotel at 5am, we were lucky that our hotel catered giving us a awesome breakfast pack.   We were greeted with other tours lining up in the morning to get tickets, one word of advice is also to dress warm as in the morning it was VERY cold.  The national park also restricts bringing in any food and you are checked at the entry point, it was strange however to see other tourists eating at the peak, i wasn't sure why our drink was confiscated.  The hike was amazing, one of the best experiences ever, in the morning the hike was sublime, the pure calm and beautiful scenery was amazing, the best part was that luckily we had a good guide and was able to take a different route where we didn't see anyone.  It felt like the whole park was ours, it was an amazing hike, to the peak the view was amazing and by the time we made it fortunately was much warmer.  The hike wasn't too difficult and on the way back we saw bucket loads of tourists coming so it was another benefit to go when we did.

You need to be here early to miss the build up of mist. We arrived around 06.50 and we certainly were not some of the first here. Despite what some people say, this is a pretty tough walk. I'm relatively fit but I'd still call it a challenging walk. My Fitbit recorded 17500 steps and 171 floors. I hate to tarnish an entire country but we were again inflicted to Chinese tourist hooligans. These moronic individuals who are only interested in taking posed selfies of themselves with 'V' fingers need to be taught how to be a tourist and respect others. We had seen it at religious sites where they run everywhere, shouting and pushing and completely disrespecting other people's religion. Today it was the utter disrespect of nature. Signs ask to be quiet, this is a place to take in the landscape, to listen to the wind. This is not a place to have Timberlake coming out of your I Phone at full blast As no one else was saying anything I'm afraid some Anglo Saxon words about their parentage was uttered and I guess they understood as they put their earphones on!!!! We were lucky to see the very rare bear monkey, an animal that is incredibly shy. Everyone around was hushed and we were able to see this amazing animal. Despite sushhhing and pointing to the monkey so they too could see it, these imbecilic people started to whistle at it like you would a dog. The monkey disappeared. At Worlds End again it was the Chinese that pushed to get the best vantage point to get selfies of themselves. China has just started tourism and this problem will only grow. Everyone appears aware of it but no one is teaching them that there are ways to be a respectable tourist. Our guide said this happens all the time. Perhaps responsible tourism behavior needs to be taught in school? The walk as mentioned is challenging, some good walking shoes should prevent slips. We saw people in flip flops. We also saw tourists with small children. This is not the place to take children. It is challenging enough on some of the steeper climbs, but looking after or carrying a child is an accident waiting to happen. It will be completely boring for them anyway and a pain for the parent. The drive from Nuwara is in the dark and  therefore you don't see much, but coming back its a great drive and you see plenty of local life with good photo opportunities.

Horton Plains is an important area for nature and conservation this must be it's primary function and restrictions on where you can wander around are understandable. That said, the entrance fee of about ¬£15 per person for what turned out to be a half day trip seems excessive. We arrived at opening time to see birds and didn't do the world's end walk, which is what most of the tourists were going for. I saw all of the species that I wanted to and was very pleased. The open air toilets were a great design and odour free. I hope the money spent goes to a good cause. In the UK national parks are free and most other countries that I've visited they only charge a nominal entrance fee. Sri Lanka could get a bad reputation for ripping off tourists. We've regularly come across one price for locals and a much larger one for foreigners. The recent implementation of free tourist visas for stays of less than one month is a great way of encouraging tourists to return after the Easter bombings. We came for two months and had to pay ¬£160, we've spent a lot of money in that time. We'd consider returning but please reduce the visa fees.
amazing location beautiful view of sunrise many deer there lovely waterfall is very good clean location

Nice walk through the countryside. Track is sometimes slipery and muddy with tree roots, so do not go here in slippers. You can se here wild animals (deer, birds). If you wanna see the Worlds end. Definataly go there as soon as possible due to the clouds. Also in later time it should be overcrowded by other tourist.
This one is definately a case of fleece the tourist. Its a nice area, but there are equal places of note that are free or a lot cheaper.

A wonderful hike through bush and across plains to Baker's Falls - senstational, Little World's End and World's End.These last two offer spectacular views when there is a break form the swirling mist. Even the mist is amazing to watch as it swirls in and out. It is very peaceful and not at all crowded. It is hard to reach without a driver. The train stops 5 1/2 kms from the entrance and it is a hard walk. There were no tuk tuks or drivers waiting at the train to drive people. If you an get there, it is definitely worth the effort.

We were their early morning and i would suggest to everyone to wear layered clothes as in the early morning due to low clouds it will be chilly. Then you start the trek which approximately take 3 to 4 hrs depends on how much time you spend taking pictures and gaze to the lovely views. 2 main highlights which are the End of world (for landscaping views) and the  Baker falls (waterfall). Worth the time for this trek i really recommend to go üëå
This is my best national park to like visit again and again in every year. Every thing is very beautiful and windblown. I and my wife visited this national park last year.

We were on a small group tour and the walk to World's End and Baker's Fall has been one of the highlights of our trip so far. You need to start early as otherwise the clouds roll in and you can't see the view. It's cold up there at that time of morning so take plenty of layers as later it gets really warm. I started with a down jacket over the top and ended up in a T shirt! Take hats and sunscreen too and sensible enclosed walking shoes. Quite rightly they don't allow any plastic containers in the park (other than water bottles with labels removed), so be prepared for a thorough bag check on arrival. I applaud this as there was almost no litter on the whole trek. There are toilets strategically placed throughout the park which I didn't use but others said they were fine. Would recommend this if you are reasonably fit. It's 9 kilometres and over quite slippery rocks at times so if you have agility problems you might struggle. I wouldn't want to do it in the rain but we had a beautiful day with great views from World's End.

We left at 5 a.m. and it took us 2 hours to reach the entrance to the National Park. There was already a long queue for tickets. It was quite cold then, and we were glad we had worn our jackets. At the entrance, they checked our bags for plastic. They even removed the plastic wrapping on the water bottles. That was impressive. It was a 7 km trek through various type of terrain. We saw a couple of deer grazing at the start of our trek. We took the route towards the right and were glad of having started early, as it was already beginning to get warm. Half way through we reached Baker's falls which was a wonderful sight. We continued on our way through rocky terrain at times and as we neared the point called World's End,we saw this amazing view of clouds coming down. We reached there and felt that we were literally among the clouds. We could not see anything below the cliff. The clouds were covering the view. After this point comes Little World's End and then the hike back is through shaded areas. Here you get to hear the sounds of different birds. Maybe if we had binoculars we would have been able to see them.

This place was definitely worth the 5am start. We got there early and were leaving before it started to get very busy. It took us 2.5 hours to do the hike around, amazing scenery, wonderful views, loads of deer. Two toilet facilities on the way around which was great. Bring water, a light jacket and runners. Get there early or the clouds can come in quick and you won't see anything. Highly recommend! Medium level of fitness required.

A hikers paradise with windy roads with different terrain. Bakers falls ,Worlds end are sights you need to let your eyes feast on, I wish they had marked `you are here' points with the amount of km's Make sure you start early morning to see the wild life

Got in my hike for the new year. Woke up at 430 am to arrive at Horton Plains at 630 am. Got our tickets and started our hike around 715 am. Get a jacket as the early morning‚Äôs temperature dipped to 12 Celsius. The terrain is relatively easy and took us 3.5 hours to complete the full loop. Fabulous hike around waterfalls, Plains, jungle and ridiculous views. Takes about 2 hours from car park to car park taking in all the sights. Fully worth it! 6 hours of leisure walk thru the Plains and enroute seeing sambars and squirrels and birds tweekings .. worth the hassle of getting up early in the morning And to top it all we saw mountain lions , while we were driving out the exit , trying to take picture of a sambar. If you're a little lucky you can walk on your own and enjoy the amazing landscapes and maybe see some animals. But most likely you have to share the way with many other people speaking loud or even playing music from their cell phones.

We arrived just after watching the sunrise from a vantage point on road up to the park. Yes up and up and up. Roughly about ¬£17 entrance fee. The 9km walk can be a bit challenging walking shoes helpful, though met young monk who was bare foot. Views are awe inspiring, and view points can be crowded, with many nationalities each with there own etiquette. You should get there early we arrived around 6.30am Reason being you come for the views and wildlife, ad we left around 10.30 clouds were already beginning to drift towards the park. We hired a driver from Nuwara Eliya to get here-- about 1 hour drive. It's a nice, easy, circular hike-- 9km in total and takes about 3 hours. Nice view point of World's End and Baker's Waterfall is beautiful. If you're lucky you'll see the purple faced monkey. Entrance is quite expensive, 3,650 rupee ($21).
Great place for a walk. I‚Äôm only giving it 3 stars due to the over priced entrances fees. $21usd to walk around is very expensive and is outrages. The views are amazing though

Horton Plains Park is a nice hiking area. We enjoyed more than 10 km hiking towards the amazing water falls and coming back The weather was incredibly magnificent and unbelievable. Please note that the distance to the falls is not indicated all the way through and it‚Äôs only indicated at the beginning of the hike. If hiking is a must-do activity, go for it.  If not, pass.  9 kilometers with moderate climbing and passing through rocks, the World's End offers a view that is way less spectacular than hiking trails in other places.  It claims to house the most bird species within the country, but I saw a few only and the birds are mostly common in shape and small in size. This national park is absolutely beautiful. We visited early morning and it was cloudy and misty. It has a beautiful landscape covered with montane grassland, located in central highlands in Sri Lanka. There are a lot of flora and fauna that you can see them clearly if it is not misty. we got a guided walk and our guide was very knowledgeable about the area. we recommend to take this safari walk and expect to be wet.

Well worth the 5.30am start. We were even lucky with the rain stopping when we arrived and clear views at World's End. So lovely to walk through this beautiful national park which is well looked after and no plastic! Definitely recommend the walk up next to mini world's end which was a discovery - great views too. A lovely 9km adventure! However since it was pouring the day before- there was huge puddles that you could not avoid- so I recommend taking wellies on this hike. Worth the visit though. Lovely waterfall, however it was too foggy to view the world‚Äôs end.

It is worth walking the distance just to witness the famous worlds end.  The walk is about 3 miles, which is not yoo far and there is plenty to stop and see along the way. There are birds of different kinds everywhere, as well as plenty of animals, including the deer.  We were lucky enough that one got  very close on our way back to the car park! There is a very nice waterfall in Horton plains too, which is worth taking a small detour for.  It was brilliant to be able to get so close to it. Magnificent views. You are up with the clouds. Water fall was great as a side walk. 2hr hike return for average person.

It was a pleasant walk through the cloud forest. Fortunately, It was not too crowded. We enjoyed the breathtaking view of the plains. We saw sambar deer at the plains. It was misty and cold. I would recommend to anyone visiting Nuwareliya to go there.

Awesome walk with nice weather. We stayed the the plains green bungalow. Nayana the manager was kind enough to come with us on our track. His knowledge and love for nature made the visit even more wonderful.

I did the forest walk in the hills with a guide who recommended we leave Nuwara Eliya at 5:30am, so could start the walk at 6:30am. An early start means less likely to have mist & cloud. The guide recommended we go left at the initial branch in the track so more likely to see Worlds‚Äô End views without cloud and then go to Baker Falls. Nice views down to valleys and lakes from the two viewing points.  I should have read TripAdvisor first as then I would have packed the right shoes - I did the walk in sandals and coped ok with only a few slips, by being cautious, but it was rocky, slippery & muddy in places so would have been better in sneakers or hiking boots. The walk took me about 3 hours - the guide says it often takes 4 hours. I heard monkeys but didn‚Äôt see them. I did see a mongoose close up. Some sambar deer on the drive in & out.

The nature is great, the hike adequate for kids- not too hard and quiet interesting with monkeys and birds appearing here and there. Gorgeous 8-9km hike. Unfortunately we started our hike too late so we got caught in a gigantic cloud which made some of the parts slippery and we couldn‚Äôt see ANYTHING of ‚Äúworld‚Äôs end‚Äù. Nonetheless it‚Äôs a gorgeous part of this world and shouldn‚Äôt be missed. It took us about 2 hours but then we didn‚Äôt hang around the sights too long and it wasn‚Äôt busy. We arrived by 630 and got dropped off at the main car park for Worlds End You will come to the point where the path splits, we went right as had read this way is much quieter and it's TRUE - it's like you have the whole place to yourself, we didn't really pass anyone until over half way as those that went left passed us! It's not rock climbing but there are definitely areas that require effort and thought The views are incredible Out of this world worth every step We are fairly fit and active and took us just under three hours There are about 3 loo stops on the loop which I was really impressed with

It was a tough six hours trek through the Plains. Plains could be misleading, as the tek involves quite a rocky terrain as well as slippery slopes. Would advise attempting this, when it is not raining and definitely with proper shoes.

The hike itself is beautiful. If you go in oktober make sure to go early in the morning due to usual afternoon rains (this goes for any activity). Cause it's the lower season it's not too crowded with people. The tracks are mostly gravelly to rocky with plenty of muddy parts on the Plains part of the hike (world's end to Baker falls and back to the entrance). So bring decent shoes! It's doable on most type of shoes, but anything with good profile on them will give you a bit more traction and make the hike easier and more enjoyable. Horton Plains National Park is one of the most beautiful natural places on Earth. It is a tranquil place highly recommended for honeymooners. We would love to visit this amazing place again!

Super cool. Super mystery. You need to go there at 4 a.m, park opens at 6. You‚Äôll see amazing sunrise on the road there. If clouds would be there, we think , it‚Äôs much more cooler. Early morning  walk to the end of the world .Conservation at it's best  prior  to admission onto the plains your requested to take nothing with you that could litter the area.Drink bottles allowed . My lovely wife and I took the morning hike through Horton Plains National Park to World's End. It's a hugely popular hike but in truth is rather unremarkable. The trail meanders through rather mundane scenery to the lookout point which offers pretty impressive views. Having said that, I wasn't entirely blown away by them. There are, for example, plenty of vistas in Scotland that are equally if not more impressive. The high numbers of visitors mean there isn't a great deal of wildlife to be seen. Entry fees for the two of us came to around 8,000 rupees (¬£35, $44, ‚Ç¨40) which is just crazy. You'll also have to pay transport costs on top of that - for example we paid 3,000 rupees (¬£13, $17, ‚Ç¨15) for a tuk tuk from Nuwara Eliya. And it simply isn't worth the money for what it is.

The Horton Plains National Park is definitely worth it. The ‚Äúend of the world‚Äù provides a stunning view over the valley. The 9km itinerary is very enjoyable and spectacular. The place is beautiful, with a few hidden gems around, worthwhile. But we felt that the entrance ticket was a bit overpriced.

Hortan plains is a plateau set on high mountains of Sri Lanka. It sits at a height of more than 2000 meters above sea level. This plateau spreads over 3150 hectares, and is a great attraction to both local and foreign tourists. It can be reached by motorable road from Pattipola or Ohiya. When you climb from below you can see how vegetation differs and weather becomes colder. When you enter the plateau you see it‚Äôs covered with mist and stunted trees due to the strong winds on the plains. Also you can find small ponds of water with water lilies. As you go further the trees become fewer but instead there are low growing bushes and more of a moor type of vegetation. Main attraction in Hortan plains is ‚ÄòWorlds End, a 700 meter breathtaking sheer drop. This drop has the most magnificent view of the sourthern wall of central highlands. Another attraction is Baker‚Äôs falls. It can be reached after a long walk through the forest. The plains are home for leopards,elk, monkeys and jackals. Plain is also home for many endemic plants. When you make a visit please make sure you do not harm the plants and animals and you will only observe the beauty of it. Worth making a trip.

World‚Äôs End was an anticlimax, and we had good weather there. It is a good 9 km walk with varied terrain, scenery and views but nothing special compared with many walks in the UK‚Äôs National Parks and elsewhere in the world.  Not worth the early start and high fees and getting there is not simple.  We were travelling from Nuwara Eliya to Ella, so did the World‚Äôs End walk on the way. We hired a car and driver for LRK10,000.  The Horton Plains NP fee for two people, plus the car and driver was LKR8,100.  Apart from the first kilometre or so there is no sign of the money raised from foreign tourists being used to maintain the route.  In places the path would become a watercourse after rain, luckily it was dry when we were there. I have no problem with foreigners being charged more than locals but the price charged should be reasonable and it would be good to see the money generated being invested in the site.
The most beautiful hike we had in Sri Lanka. Worthy to go early on the morning, and worthy even without the view - often foggy. No leeches :)

Ticket price is well worth it. Grassland plains, mangrove forests. There is a restaurant outside the gate were you can refresh yourself . We paid LKR 7,950.00 for 2 person incl all. for the entrance ticket.

This national park is the source for four of Sri Lanka's major rivers, so it's not unusual to experience a bit of rain. Fortunately, the heavy rain dropped the night before our 9.5 km trek through the park, which took in the spectacular World's End. It made some uneven parts of the trail a bit slippery, so solid hiking shoes or, at minimum runners, are essential. Only a moderate level of fitness is required to navigate the main trail, which takes in World's End and Bakers Falls. However, anyone with some walking or climbing disability should take note that there are those uneven areas to negotiate. World's End is so called because of its 900 metre vertical cliff face that drops into the forest of the valley wall. It's hard to capture its scale in photographs. There are two viewing decks at World's End. Beware, particularly for children, that there are few barriers to prevent falls over the cliffs, both on the decks and on the short trail between decks. My impression was that the coiled razor wire would merely lacerate you during the fall rather than prevent it. The higher deck gives a much better view of the main cliff face. The steps down to Bakers Falls are also quite steep. Hortons Plains features a wide variety of landscape and an explosion of different colours from the many plant species that adorn the plain. The area is also a good place to see Sambar Deer, one of Sri Lanka's larger deer species.

I was traveling alone and staying in a guest house in Nuwara Eliya so my transportation was arranged for by my wonderful hosts, but my tour guide/driver picked me up at 5am to take me out to Horton Plains. We got there early a) to beat the crowds, and b) because I had an afternoon train to Ella to catch, but we actually got there so early that the ticket office hadn't opened yet. The hike isn't too difficult, it's about 8 miles with a few portions of steeper climbing, but getting there in the morning allows you to see some GORGEOUS views. My driver gave me the tip of sitting and waiting at World's End because a lot can change in the scenery in a matter of minutes, and it was the best advice. I ate snacks I packed (remember to do this) and took a 40 minute rest up there and watched in awe as clouds and fog came in and out (at one point completely blocking the view and then clearing up to reveal a gorgeous drop and the plains beyond). I wanted to take pictures every time I turned the corner because I was treated to new views every mile or so - the diversity in ecosystems and flora/fauna is INSANE. If you're in Nuwara Eliya, make sure you make time for this hike! I actually stopped in Nuwara Eliya JUST so I could get out here! Definitely get an early start (apparently sometimes in the morning you can see deer and elephants if it's early enough!) so you're hiking when it's cooler and to beat the crowds.

We had a very unfortunate experience when buying tickets to enter Horton Plains National Park. We visited on the morning of Friday 12th July. Apologies for the long and less than positive review, I am also posting this hoping someone may be able to point me towards a way to lodge a complaint with the Park itself as I haven‚Äôt been able to find this online. Ticket prices are not advertised as prices tend to fluctuate so there is no price list at the ticket booth. We asked for ‚Äú3 tickets, one person is local‚Äù, however this was interpreted as 3 tickets plus one local. A foreigner ticket at the time was ~2,650 rupees. With no price list, visitors the transaction is based purely on verbal communication with no calculator or screen to show how prices are calculated (there are three taxes on top of the ticket price). Understandably this is also a quick, rushed process during busy times such as when we visited. Unfortunately, we were unable to realise we were overcharged until we had driven 10 minutes from the ticket office to the park entrance. At the park entrance we spoke with a number of staff and based on what they advised we decided to enter the park rather than drive back and seek a refund (lucky we did this because as we found out, we would not have been refunded anyway and it would have ruined our visit). On our way out we approached the ticket booth and fortunately the same cashier was working (a middle aged man, moustache, larger, has worked at the park for over 15 years). We were very careful to politely inform that we were accidentally overcharged (e.g. we avoided saying ‚Äúyou overcharged us‚Äù, instead saying ‚Äúwe were accidentally overcharged‚Äù) however he immediately went on the defensive, became very rude and irrational and refused to help us. He accused us of being irresponsible and not communicating with him properly. He also said there is no possibility of a refund once a sale has been made and its the customers responsibility to know what they are being charged and that he does not make mistakes so it must be our fault. When we tried to explain that we were not trying to pass blame and a simple misunderstanding had occurred, he became argumentative and started insulting our tour guide/driver in Sinhalese and saying he was not looking after us properly. He refused to call the park manager (he said there was no phone reception, although all three of us had reception) and said nobody would help us because it was our fault. There was lots of back and forth about ticket prices not being advertised, no way of knowing what we have been charged for until transaction has been finalised etc. until we finally decided that nothing we did or said would help us obtain a refund. Overall, this left a very sour taste in our mouths and our tour guide/driver felt ashamed that a park ranger would behave in this way. Unfortunately, the cashier did not have an ounce of empathy and his behaviour screamed dishonesty and not a care on the world for doing what is right. Had he at least even tried to help us in the slightest, our experience with him would have been completely difference. Lesson: when buying tickets and you have a local guide to accompany you, be very clear to say X foreigner tickets and Y local ticket. Avoid assuming any statements like ‚Äú3 people, one is local‚Äù as this will be interpreted as 3 foreigners, one local‚Äù. As for the park itself, it is beautiful and the views are amazing. It was lovely walking through such stunning scenery. However, the price is quite high especially in comparison to similar yet free experiences we have had in Sri Lanka as well as other national parks we have visited around the world.

The journey over in the dark was, well, interesting - low-lying mist on the unlit roads, speeding drivers trying to overtake at all opportunities (it is Sri Lanka after all!) and low powered tuktuk lights all made for a memorable trip!  After buying our entry tickets ($45 for two people including all fees and taxes) we headed up to the trail head as the sun was coming up, with a few scattered deer out on the plains - fairly magical!  The hike itself is a circular, so you can head either clockwise or anticlockwise - most guides say to go anticlockwise, as you reach Little World's End before World's End but we opted for the latter and didn't regret it at all - it's slightly easier as you get a flattish finish, and you also avoid most of the crowds - once we'd headed out the only people we saw for the first 4km or so were the quicker hikers heading past us (not sure why, this is the sort of place that deserves you take your time to soak in the atmosphere!)  The early start was a killer at 4.30am, but seemed like a great idea now - the light is beautiful at that time of day and there's still the early morning frost on the ground and low-lying mist in the valleys.  Baker Falls are nice (but no Iguazu!) and the views from World's End and it's little brother are great, but for me the real winner was the hike and the scenery - just magical at that time of day, and we felt at times we were no longer in Sri Lanka but maybe south America!  While we didn't see much wildlife on the outward part of the hike we saw quite a bit when heading back after Little World's End - a couple of giant squirrels and a few purple-faced leaf monkeys enjoying a feed in the early morning sun - plus quite a few birds.  The round trip is around 9km or so, but we took our time enjoying the journey.  Very highly recommended if you're in Nuwara Eliya - indeed, probably the best thing you can do here IMO!

Horton Plains is a gently undulating highland plateau at 2,100.meters above sea level of Sri Lanka,lying at the south end of the central highlands. It is dominated by Kirigalpoththa (2.389 meters) to west and Totupolakanda (2,357 meters) to the north. Kirigalpoththa and Totupolakanda are the second and third highest mountains in Sri Lanaka. Tha charm of the plateau and encircling mountain range, often concealed mist, is enhanced by Baker's Falls and the two two escarpments, Small Worlds End (274 meters) and Big Worlds End (884 meters). The plateau is drained by tributaries of Mahaweli Ganga (main river of Sri Lanka) to the north (Agra Oya) and the Walawe Ganga to the south (Belihul Oya), serving as an important catchment area for these two rivers which have been harnessed for irrigation and hydro power. This plateau consists of many Amphibians, three types of harmless reptiles, birds and mammals including the leopard. Access to the plains are mainly from Ohiya, Pattipola and Nuwara Eliya. There are foot trails from Nagarak Trail is from the Agrapathana - Diyagama Tea Estate and also from Belihul Oya which falls into the same Nagarak Trail. This is place you must visit and possible to camp in the camping site. Plenty of Wildlife and ideal location for a wildlife photographer like me who is looking for adventure  .

As suggested by a few blogs, I was wearing 5 layers of warm clothing. We got off the cab and went to join the long queue for the entrance tickets. The cold was unbearable and soon we were shivering. Thankfully the tickets were finally sorted out and we got back in the cab, to drive towards the entrance gate. The fog had slowly started to clear up as we started with the walk. It was a three hour closed trail, a simple trek with a little up and down slopes and a little rocky patches here and there. Nothing scary. The fog is basically created by cloud forests in the Horton‚Äôs plains. Luckily enough, the sun popped out of the clouds, clearing up the fog. The Baker‚Äôs falls offered a pretty view. We got clear, unhindered views form World‚Äôs end view point. What Luck! But then, the views were actually not that impressive. And the walk was not that challenging. I would like to mention one impressive thing about the management of Horton plains. At the entrance, they have a baggage check point where no tourist is allowed to proceed with a piece of plastic, may it be a bag or a bottle or a chewing gum box, thus keeping Horton plains plastic free. I think this is a very sensible step and ideally should be followed everywhere around the world.

Go there early, as early as you can, to beat the mist. Wear comfortable footwear and your bottles of water cannot be covered with paper. It's a lot of walking, climbing and will require you to be moderately fit. We did the whole shebang including the falls, and that took us about 3 hours. Once you arrive, you have two options, either to continue straight or go left, we went left. Our guide said we should reach the little and big world's ends before 9:30 so the mist doesn't settle in and he was right. If we had been 15 minutes late, we wouldn't have seen anything. The mist covered the whole area 5 minutes after we were done taking pictures. It was beautiful to see the cloudy body follow us and then cover us as we continued trekking throughout the planes. You can take a snack with you and eat it on top of big world's end, it's a beautiful place, cannot describe it in words. Really worth the visit and the workout !
The walk through the Horton Plains National Park was gorgeous. Nature pure, amazing fews from World‚Äôs End and Little World‚Äôs End! Highly recommended!

The 9km route is relatively easy, with mostly flat terrain but a few patches of bouldering and climbing that does make it trickier in parts. Allow for about 3 to 3.5 hours if you stick to the path (we veered off a bit and extended our walk off the beaten track). The viewpoints are quite spectacular and the surroundings serene. A worthwhile excursion.

A great opportunity to enjoy the splendor of nature and spend the day actively! Wake up early, obligatory comfortable shoes,headcover, protective cream, sunglasses and drinking water. If you arrive early, you need a jacket, in the morning in early May it was cool. Before entering the territory of the reserve, a ticket office with a queue for 10 - 20 minutes. We were with a personal guide who took care of entrance tickets but you can go by  yourself (get lost if you do not turn off the way is impossible). There is a parking before the start of the route, where both the touristic and personal cars park. There is also a cafe that looks rather suspicious, but our guide said that it is possible to have a tea and eat traditional pastries. It was not bad! The toilet is located at the back of the cafe, it is better to visit it, because there are no more lavatories on the entire route. Despite the clouds during the entire walk and a fairly cool temperature in the morning in the first 2 hours, the noses and cheeks burned, so you must always apply a protective cream, then a walk of at least 9 km will be comfortable and enjoyable. The road in places is sometimes rather stony and difficult, therefore it is better to choose another occupation for children and people with limited motor abilities. The nature is amazing, the silence, the singing of birds and the murmur of water in streams, passing into small rivers and waterfalls are interrupted only by groups of passing tourists. Early in the morning saw one deer and several roe deer grazing not so far from the cafe. On the way there were chameleons and earthen small lizards, many birds. We did not hurry, we admired the surrounding nature for a long time, and after 6 hours we completed the ring of the route. A nice rest for everyone who is going to Horton Plains!

This was one of my highlights in Sri Lanka! The views are incredible! The walk is very enjoyable! Make sure to get there early so you can enjoy all the view before the mist rolls in! I would consider this a must if visiting Sri Lanka!

It was a lovely hike to view worlds end and mini worlds end. Loved the view. Would recommend bringing water, and wearing proper shoes. Also snacks! It s advised to go during early morning and not late evenings. The view is worth the climb.

Loved the loop hike. Go early to avoid crowd we were at the gate at 6. Really nice hike seeng World Ends, waterfall and nature at its best. Absolutely no plastic is allowed past the starting point and I am very impressed. They checked our backpacks and removed even plastic labels from water bottle! The hike was plastic free so I think it's a great idea!!

We left at 5:30 am from our hotel in nuwara Eliya to start our hike at 7am. The journey was around an hour in a TUK TUK (2500rps return journey) with 30 mins cueing. Most people come at this time to avoid peak heat and to see the views at worlds end without clouds. The route although not sign posted well can be done easily without a guide. Don‚Äôt worry there‚Äôll be plenty of walkers around from all ages doing the walk at the ungodly hour. You can choose 2 routes: route 1 is the one to your left and goes straight when you reach it. This will take you to mini worlds end, worlds end and bakers fall in that order. Plus point - you‚Äôll def get to the main attraction without clouds. Down side is you‚Äôll have a harder trek back uphill. Route 2- this is the one we chose. The path when you reach the first bifurcation is the one going down the steps ahead of you. This will lead you to bakers falls, worlds end and mini worlds end in this order. Plus point - it‚Äôs an easier journey back as it‚Äôs mainly downhill returning. Down side - by the time we got to mini worlds end it was so cloudy we couldn‚Äôt see the view! Either way both routes are around 11 km loop. It‚Äôs relatively easy- just feels very long and you get hot! Took us 4 hours at a leisurely pace. Make sure you get your hotel to pack you a breakfast box so you can eat it when you‚Äôre having a break there. The cost of the ticket depends on how many of you are there in your group- the more of you going the cheaper it will be individually. For 2 of us it cost 3315 each ( including our TUK TUK drivers entrance). If you‚Äôre in Nuwara Eliya a visit isn‚Äôt complete without a hike in hortons plain. The view from worlds end is AMAZING!

its an amazing place to be. i was told that you need to be at the plains by 6 o'clock as soon as the park opens to have a quiet view of the trail and mother nature. leaving by 4.30 totally worth it. i reached in time and its not like no-one was there, but very few. totally enjoyes the sun rise and then the trail on the park is beautiful as well. do remember that it gets crowded by 10'ish and youight want to avoid that. its almost 8 kilometers trail and it takes around 3 hours very easily even when you are continuously walking. stay healthy ppl!!!

Horton Plains is worth visiting if you do enjoy a good hike. Also; the landscapes are beautiful and very different from what you'll see in other parts of Sri Lanka. It is a bit pricey though, and I wouldn't recommend visiting Horton Plains for World's End alone. If you're not that much into nature or walking: don't come here! You can see equally impressive or better views for free at other places in Sri Lanka and it'll save you the money and time to get there. People with mobility problems may find this hike less enjoyable, because the trail can be challenging in places and paths can get slippery after rainfall.

We arrived at 6am in order to walk to World's End before mist came down. We had a fantastic 10km walk and the views from World's End were truly stupendous. We saw a few birds but not much more by way of wildlife. Nonetheless, the walk was a highlight of our trip to Sri Lanka. There is a small exhibition and (paid) toilets. I was a bit miffed to see that the exhibition asks what damage you have done by visiting the park that day: if visitor numbers are such a concern, then perhaps pricing and entrance policies should be amended rather than passively criticising the people who have paid $25 for the privilege of visiting the park.

If you're into walking I would highly recommend the walk through Horton Plains to World's End! The scenery is beautiful! There are rolling hills, a beautiful waterfall and spectacular views from both World's End and Mini World's End. Tips: - Go early! The walk takes about 3 hours in total and about 1.5 hours from the starting Point to reach World's End (the main viewing point) We left our hotel in Newara Eliya at 5.30 and started walking at 7am. - Wear runners and comfortable clothes - I'd recommend layers (as it can be chilly at 7am and very warm by 9am). We were lucky with the weather but apparently it rains at lot so bring a raincoat). - Do the walk anti-clockwise! There's a main path from the carpark up to the start of the loop. At the sign board go straight ahead (most people to left). The first part of the walk is open to the elements so offers beautiful views as the sun rises and it's nicer to do this part of the walk when it's a little cooler (If you walk in the other direction there is little shelter from the sun as you're returning). Also there are less crowds at the waterfall!

The trek is around 10 km ... the place is around an hours drive from nuwara Eliya . Try and head out early cos if u r late the views at the worlds end would be covered in mist . We did the trek at the end of march the weather was pretty good . Carry a bottle of water and some light snacks as there is nothing available on the route inside . A small shop located outside sells water biscuits and basic Sri Lankan snacks

I was there with my family during the sinhala/tamil new year season. Perhaps due to season in Nuwara Eliya the park was absolutely crowded. Which we did not like that much but i think this is not something we can't avoid. However the park was spectacular as ever. weather was very kind to us in everyway. We had a perfect day.
